titlestmt.titleproper: A Guide to the Maps and flat files FA465

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2025-01-01 05:01:54 UTC.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access note
accessrestrict.p: Open for research with select materials restricted as noted. Retrieval times for maps and flat files may exceed 24 hours.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: Maps and flat files are arranged in 56 series, according to the archival collection that the material originated from, or by subject matter (when original provenance is not known). Series are further arranged in subseries when applicable.

Series 1: Rockefeller Foundation. Series 2: Office of the Messrs. Rockefeller. Series 3: Rockefeller Family and Associates: Tioga Series. Series 4: Nelson A. Rockefeller papers. Series 5: John D. Rockefeller 3rd. Series 6: Pocantico Hills. Series 7: Hillcrest. Series 8: Rockwood Hall. Series 9: Laurance S. Rockefeller. Series 10: Nelson A. Rockefeller Gubernatorial records. Series 11: Blanchette H. Rockefeller. Series 12: Sleepy Hollow Restorations/Historic Hudson Valley. Series 13: Rockefeller University. Series 14: Ford Foundation. Series 16: Agricultural Development Council, Inc. Series 17: American Council for Arts in Education. Series 18: China Medical Board, Inc. Series 19: Commonwealth Fund. Series 20: Russell Sage Foundation. Series 21: Archdiocese: Russell Sage Foundation. Series 22: Goldstone and Hinz. Series 23: Grand Teton Lodge Company. Series 24: Hudson Hills Press. Series 25: International Business Economic Corporation (IBEC). Series 26: International Education Board (IEB). Series 27: JY Ranch. Series 28: Jackson Hole Preserve, Inc. (JHPI). Series 29: JDR 3rd Fund. Series 30: Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center (MSKCC). Series 31: Near East Foundation (NEF). Series 32: Population Council. Series 33: Social Science Research Council (SSRC). Series 34: Sealantic Fund. Series 35: Simpson family papers. Series 36: Alfred E. Cohn papers, Rockefeller University faculty. Series 37: Hao Wang papers, Rockefeller University faculty. Series 38: Laura Spelman Rockefeller Memorial. Series 39: Conrad W. Anner. Series 40: John C. Bugher. Series 41: John R. Camp. Series 42: Kenneth Chorley. Series 43: Harold P. Fabian. Series 44: Charles Burton Fahs. Series 45: Lawrence B. Dunham. Series 46: Paul Ehrlich. Series 47: Lewis W. Hackett. Series 48: John H. Knowles. Series 49: Leopold Koss. Series 50: William M. Myers. Series 51: Leonard Outhwaite. Series 52: Oscar M. Ruebhausen. Series 53. Benjamin E. Washburn. Series 54: Joseph Willits. Series 55: John D. Rockefeller 3rd Associates: Edgar B. Young. Series 56: Hudson Highlands. Series 57: Miscellaneous.

processinfo.head: Processing Information note
processinfo.p: Since the contents of the Maps and flat files has inherently been separated from other archival holdings, the description of any individual item, or set of items, may also currently appear, in some form, in the finding aid for the originating collection.
Future processing, description, and presentation of the Maps and flat files will seek to address this issue as much as feasible.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Maps and flat files is an artificial collection created by the RAC in order to efficiently and effectively manage and present the oversized flat materials across all our archival holdings.

This material includes but is not necessarily limited to: architectural drawings, artwork, blueprints, charts, citations, oversized documents, graphs, maps, photographs, posters, publications, renderings, whiteprints, and other such items that necessitate flat storage.

separatedmaterial.head: Separated Materials note
separatedmaterial.p: The majority of the maps and flat files have been physically separated from an archival collection.
When the specifics of this separation are known, the details are provided either in this finding aid, or writen on a separation sheet physically accompanying the item.
In many cases, the specific details of the provenance are simply unknown.
